segments.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yatthimā mahānadiyo saṃsandanti samenti, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: “Mendicants, there are places where the great rivers—the Ganges, Yamuna, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—come together and converge.

segments.pli: gaṅgā, yamunā, aciravatī, sarabhū, mahī, taṃ udakaṃ parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, ṭhapetvā dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni.
segments.en: Suppose that water dried up and evaporated except for two or three drops.

segments.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yaṃ vā saṃbhejjaudakaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ, yāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhānī”ti?
segments.en: Which is more: the water in the confluence that has dried up and evaporated, or the two or three drops left?”

segments.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ saṃbhejjaudakaṃ yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ; appamattakāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhāni.
segments.en: “Sir, the water in the confluence that has dried up and evaporated is certainly more. The two or three drops left are tiny.

segments.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti saṃbhejjaudakaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ upanidhāya dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhānī”ti.
segments.en: Compared to the water in the confluence that has dried up and evaporated, it can’t be reckoned or compared, it’s not even a fraction.”
“In the same way, for a noble disciple …
That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sections.title: “Mendicants, there are places where the great rivers—the Ganges,…

suttaplex.blurb: As a few drops of water compared to confluence of the great rivers, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
